text: Arnaud wrote, I agree with the approach to calibrate to pass data and forecast, but it's already quite challenging for current models that only have a few parameters to be calibrated.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's only difficult because 99% of agent-based modeling uses the sample distribution.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You do not do that.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You use variational.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You actually simulate and roll out the probability distributions themselves using variational calculus.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that means that what was yesterday really difficult agent-based modeling and certainly epidemiological modeling now becomes really trivial, orders of magnitude more efficient.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What you have to take care of is exactly the thing that Daniel was highlighting before, which is the heterogeneity.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You need to put that into the mix and this manifests in a number of ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So when you apply variational procedures to effectively roll out population density, probability density distributions over various states of being, am I infected?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Am I staying at home?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: have I died?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You have to make sure that the heterogeneity is part of the generative model.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is sometimes called stratification.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So for example, in epidemiological models, you'd have eight bands for different age groups.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if you notice the way that
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: the epidemiological data was generated.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It was usually age segregated so that people could stratify their models.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Another way in which this heterogeneity becomes absolutely crucial when you come to agent-based modeling in the context of epidemiological or infectious disease modeling is called overdispersion.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Now, overdispersion is the fact that you get heavy-tailed distributions that inherit from the heterogeneity.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you get this for free once you put heterogeneity into the model.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But it does mean for every, if you like, subgroup of the population, you do introduce more parameters.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But remember, the number of parameters
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: doesn't really matter it's the amount of time that you take to effectively invert your model and if you try and do that using sampling based approaches which is currently the the norm you could take literally weeks to do something whereas if you use variational procedures then you could do that within within minutes so it's a really important question a very practical one
